Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an LC/MS/MS System for Multidisciplinary Research and Educational Projects

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1338088
Chen

Liquid Chromatography (LC) is widely used in analytical and bioanalytical areas as a routine technique to identify, quantify, and purify components present in a mixture. The conventional procedure for these imposes ambiguity on the results. Inclusion of Mass Spectroscopy to LC will help to minimize this uncertainty. LC/MS/MS is a powerful technique with very high sensitivity and selectivity. Generally its application is oriented towards the specific detection and potential identification of chemicals in the presence of other chemicals in a complex mixture to cover wide applications ranging from accurate mass measurement and structural characterization of unknowns to trace-level quantitative analysis. Lamar University (LU) is pursuing enhancement of their analytical capabilities for the environmental and biochemical research in both college of engineering and college of Arts & Science. The team is requesting funds for acquisition of a LC/MS/MS for faculty and student research projects and inter-university collaborative projects. Currently, there are no LC/MS or LC/MS/MS instruments on the LU campus. Researchers must get such analyses at commercial facilities where the costs and lead time are extremely high. If the LC/MS/MS can be acquired, the team plans to achieve the following two objectives: (i) basic research and development of new analysis methods in Chemical Engineering, Civil and Environmental Engineering, Chemistry and Biochemistry, and Biology, and (ii) application of the latest technology and pedagogical practices to educate students in these areas.

Overview:

Liquid Chromatography (LC) is widely used in analytical and bioanalytical areas as a routine technique to identify, quantify, and purify components present in a mixture. The conventional procedure for these imposes ambiguity on the results. Inclusion of Mass Spectroscopy to LC will help to minimize this uncertainty. LC/MS/MS becomes nowadays a powerful technique with very high sensitivity and selectivity. Generally its application is oriented towards the specific detection and potential identification of chemicals in the presence of other chemicals in a complex mixture to cover wide applications ranging from accurate mass measurement and structural characterization of unknowns to trace-level quantitative analysis. Lamar University (LU) is pursuing enhancement of their analytical capabilities for the environmental and biochemical research in both College of Engineering and College of Arts & Sciences. The acquired LC/MS/MS has facilitated faculty and student research projects and intra/inter-university collaboration.  

Intellectual Merit :

The acquired LC/MS/MS has been utilized to achieve the stated two objectives: (i) basic research and development of new analysis methods in Chemical Engineering, Civil and Environmental Engineering, Chemistry and Biochemistry, and (ii) application of the latest technology and pedagogical practices to educate students in these areas.

The instrument has been applied in the following research areas: (1) identifying and quantifying of emergent water contaminants and their degradation products during bio-, photo-, and electro-chemical treatments, (2) in situ characterization of biological or photo-degradation products of biological organisms, and of sterol substrate driven enzymatic reactions, (3) understanding the thermodynamic and kinetic photochemical factors that influence photon driven organic reaction mechanisms by carefully tracing intermediates and products, (4) investigating phthalate leaching from food packaging and children’s toys, (5) studying electrocatalytic oxidation and electrocoagulation of organic pollutants in water and food, (6) identifying peptides of interest as therapeutic targets for parasitic infections, (7) elucidating the specific bond-breaking and bond-making steps in nanocomposite preparation and polymer conversion processes, (8) studying the occurrence and degradation pathways of pharmaceuticals and pesticides in wastewater, (9) identifying the intermediates of anaerobic digestion, (10) studying the biopolymers in layered matrices, (11) stabilization of dredged material using bio-enzyme products, (12) development and testing of amine-type scavengers for the removal of H2S from liquid sour crudes, (13) mutagenic study of the potential of bacteria cells on the bioremediation of heavy metals, and (14) removal of steroids and antibiotics in water using bio-sorbents. Grad and advanced undergrad students were instructed in the theory and application of LC/MS/MS in 5 grad and under grad courses and over 200 students.

Broader Impacts :

The  LC/MS/MS provides both undergraduate and graduate students at LU an opportunity to access this modern instrument through research or classroom instruction.  Further, the instrument facilitates multidisciplinary collaboration efforts inside LU from colleges of Engineering and College of Arts and Sciences. 4 female students and technicians from these two Colleges were trained with the acquired LC/MS/MS. The invited collaborators include Prairie View A&M (a traditionally African-American university) and the Technological Institute of Saltillo, Mexico (located at the border regions of Texas). Presentations, theses, and manuscripts were produced to transfer research outcomes to area, national, and international practitioners in the field of environmental engineering, science, and management.
